div.stage: Here Coopee Re-enters and Sings this Song to the Minute that he is dancing with Jenny.

lg.l: Make your Honours Misse, tholl loll loll,
Now to me Childe, tholl loll loll.
Aiery and easy now, tholl loll loll
Very well done Misse, tholl loll loll
Raise up your Body Childe, tholl loll
Then you in time will rise: hoh, tholl, la.
Hold up your head Misse, tholl loll loll
Wipe your Nose Child, tholl loll
When I press on ye, tholl loll loll
Fall back easy Misse, tholl loll loll
Keep out your toes too, tholl loll loll
Then you'l learn presently, hoh, tholl la.
Bear your hips Swimmingly, tholl loll loll
Keep your Eyes languishing, tholl loll loll
Zoons where's your Ears now? tholl loll loll
Leave off your Ierking, tholl loll loll
Keep your knees open, tholl loll loll
Else you will never do: hoh tholl la.
If you will love me Misse, tholl loll loll loll
You shall dance rarely Childe, tholl loll loll,
You are a Fortune Misse, tholl loll loll
And must be Married Child, tholl loll loll
Give me your Money Misse, tholl loll loll
Then I will give you my, hoh tholl la.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Oh dear Mr. Coopee indeed I love you very well, and will do any thing you'd have, but pray let me go now, for I'm so hungry—

sp.speaker: Coopy.
sp.p: The Poor little Tit's as coming as heart can wish, I'm resolv'd to snap her, for I hear she's a fortune and worth while.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Iane, let the Buck-basket be got ready for the foul-cloaths, de'e hear, and bid the Landress take care to mend all the shifts; these great Ramping-girles do so tear their Linnen, it almost makes me wilde.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: Your Servant Mrs Crowstich.

sp.speaker: Crow,
sp.p: How de'e Mr. Coopee, and de'e hear bid the Cook-maid Cut a hundred and fifty pieces of bread and butter round the Loaf; these Hoyden tits have plague'e Stomachs.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: What is it breakfast time with 'em already then?

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Always at nine a Clock, and they watch the hour as warily— as a Parson does his Glass-when he is tired with preaching; this is their bread and butter-days, and each of 'em has a full half yard by measure, of which if there were but an Inch wanting, the greedy things will cry they are starv'd, and complain to their parents.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Aw aw aw aw aw aw aw hum—

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: There's one now, I vow and swear Mr. Coopee I am quite tir'd with that Romp there. Coming down Stairs this morning, what do you think I saw, I protest that great Beare there getting a stride upon Iohn the Gardeners back as he was stooping down to gather a Sallet.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha—

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: What if I did? what ●●en? what need you care? pray— aw awe.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: But i'faith gentlewoman, you shall be well slash'd for't, the Governess has a Clawing Rod a making:—

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Aw aw aw aw aw aw—

div.stage: Enter Jenny with a large piece of Bread and butter.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Oh Sister, what did Iohn Gardner do to you pray? oh law, oh law—

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: What's that to you long Nose, oh law oh law.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: My Governess will order ye she vows, and I'le tell my Mother on ye I'm resolv'd, she'l be here this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: And I'le tell my Father then how you peep'd upon Mr. Coopee t'other day when he was going a Swimming.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Ay tell tell Snotty-nose, what care I, my mother can order you, and my father both pray; besides [pushes her] hussy you peep'd as well as I that you did, so you did.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Go, go baby, and make dirt-pyes again, my father says I shall have a husband shortly pray.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: You,— my mother will bring me a tall huge husband home next week and methinks I long for a tall huge husband, and I am to leave off my Bib and Apron too.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: The Maids won't lye with you, you do I know what a bed.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Oh law, that's a great lie, and I'le tear your Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Hussy I'le pull your head off

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: You shan't think to tell such Lyes on me to make Mr. Semibrief hate me, I'le tear ye alive first.

div.stage: Enter Crowstich with a great Rod.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Rare work indeed, come Gentlewoman the Governess would speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Oh oh oh—

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: So, I'm glad on't i'vads, she'l be lash'd Swingingly.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Young Merriton, Mirtilla and Coopee.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: I'le go and act a Centry without, and if any body comes this way, shoot off my piece and give ye warning.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: Ah dear Rogue I'me oblig'd to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: The reverence I have to the very Name of my worthy Foster-Father Mr. Merriton, to whom you say you are related, and to whose virtue I stand Indebted, for all the Comforts of this life makes me submit my self with more willingness to this your Importunity, else Sir believe me, I should think this lonely Visit very improper, and not at all Concurring with my honour.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: Your honour is a thing, I would defend against a World of Enemies, then think not Sweet that I would willingly do any thing to blast it, I know this private Visit may be censur'd, but not whilest 'tis a Secret, as 'tis now, I had no other way to express my Love, and not to have done it would have made me Miserable.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p:
You Imagine Sir that my Soul is Musicall, and therefore treat
me with that tunefull word; but build not Sir, too much upon my weakness, for tho' my heart is tender and unartfull, and Love a bait most proper to deceive me, yet Virtue is a guard.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: There needs no guard Sweet Angell against a Love so honourable as mine, the World is full of Treachery, and our Sex are brooding mischiefs dayly against yours, but I alas am of another Mould, my Soul by fate was design'd for your Slave, my heart still moves the narrow constant Road, in hopes in your's to finde at last it's heaven.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: Oh that bewitching tongue would charm a Saint. you are not of the humour of the Town then:

sp.speaker: Y. Merrit.
sp.p: I hate the Town and the vain Crowd are in it, the Biass'd Court and Mercenary City where gorg'd with Ignorance and Luxury, Wit is disgrac'd, the Sciences despis'd, and modest Merrit mourns in Rag's it's fortune, 'tis the Epitome of the nauseous world whose Vices I with such fell-hate persue, that I love nothing near the Town but you.

sp.speaker: Mirttill.
sp.p: In loving me you doubly wrong your self, I have Sir not power to make return.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Your heart is sure your own.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: Most certainly: but where I give a heart I'le give a Fortune, and that alas my Niggard Stars deny me, yet think not that I neglect an honest Love; for to slight Merit were a baseness in me; no, you shall find worth has a Friend of me, and shares my best acknowledgements and praise: you are a Man compleat by Heaven and Nature, most qualify'd with Wit and rarest Arts, which from my Soul I always lov'd and honour'd, and therefore she that gains ye must be happy, but I whilst stinted by Injurious fate, can bring no equall value, therefore must think ye a Jewell much too Rich for me to wear.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: How near to Heaven is my present Joy, from that sweet mouth to hear my self thus prais'd; Oh thou dear source of all my worldly blessings, Eternal Rapture charms me from thy tongue, and whilst I hear thee I am deify'd, to loose thee were Damnation so Infallible, I question whether there could be a greater.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: ●ay Rise Sir, or you'l make me dye with blushing.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: Ah make me happy then, and give consent.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: To Marriage, to perform, sweet Angell that blessed work thou wert Created for.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: Ah, Poverty and Marriage never suit.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: Thou hast all Craesus Treasure in thy Virtues, and I in gaining thee shall be far Riche.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: You think so now, but when wants make me troublesome then you'l upbraid and Chide me.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.p: Ah never, never, can I chide my Genius for making my days happy.

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: I can be Constant Sir, therefore have patience, fortune may change and give to one or t'other the Power to oblige.

sp.speaker: Y. Merr.
sp.l: A cursed Fortune, still to Justice blinde,
Averse to Merit, but to Ideots kinde:
Thou Misers Darling, and trifle of the Brave,
Niggard to the Poor, but to the Rich a Slave:
How nicely happy all Mankind would be,
Thou Nauseous Common-Whore, wer't not for thee.
How now—

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Come, come, give him your hand quickly, here's Crowstich the Teacher coming, you must dance for your Liberty now Sir.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Madam, pray do's this Implement belong to you or to Misse Scatterwater, yonder Laundry Wench will face me down, that— Bless me, who's here [sees Mer.] how now Mr. Semibrief — who'sthat there in the Ladys quarters?

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: A Brother Hop-Merchant of mine Mrs. Crowstitch that I brought here to help to teach a little, having a lame leg.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Come, come, you'l be wanted now in the Dancing-Room, there's my Lady Addleplot come already, and a great deal of good Company.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Odsoe we must make hast then, for there's to be singing besides the Entertainment of a young Indian Lady: A new Boarder that is to Dance

sp.speaker: Mirtill.
sp.p: Sir, you'l remember to teach me the new Chacune.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Any thing that's mine Madam.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: In the Front appears several of the Boarders as Seated for the Ball, and on the side of the Stage others sitting as Spectators; among the rest L. Addleplot, Tearshift: L. Stroddle, and other Ladies, and on the middle of the Stage Le Prate, Y. Bragg, and Semibrief.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ah Iernie vat a filthy place is this when compare vid our School in France, no Decorum, no Ornament, no Fresco, begar metink it stink a like a de Kitchin of de Lord Mawor— or the hold of a Ship begar.

sp.speaker: Semib.
sp.p: Ah Sir, our Noses are not so Nice here in England.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Dat is as much as say you are all Sloven in England, gazoon your Jantee French Dancing-Master, all wear persume and cover them all over vid rare Pulvile to take away de nauscous ill Ayre. Ugh— ugh,— oh fogh tis Intollerable.

div.stage: Enter Crowstich with Miss Jenny holding a Waxwork Baby in a Glass. Mirtill, Y. Merriton, and Coopee— Miss Jenny asks Blessing.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p:
Bless ye, Bless my good Child, and make her a good woman,
and the mother of many Children: I think she's grown since I saw her last Mrs Crowstich.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Mightily Madam, mightily, would she would grow in grace as much.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Lord save her pretty Moppet, hold up your head Ienny, and go and make a Courtesy to my Lady Stroddle:—

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: Your servant pretty Misse:— Indeed Madam, [Kisses her] as your Ladyship says she's grown extreamly, Misse, you are almost fit for a husband already; hah Child.

sp.speaker: Misse Ien.
sp.p: Hoh hoh hoh hoh—

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Fye Miss Ienny where are your hands now? have I not told ye, you must remember to put 'em thus always; when you make a Courtesy?

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: That's my good Girl, Mounsieur Le Prat and Cozen Bounter you don't see Misse and her fine work here.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your Ladyships pardon, and I am your most Obedient Slave pret Misse.—

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Dear Sweet Pretty Creature your's:—

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: Well I vow Madam these Nudities are very Ingenious; the Child is Extravagantly well bred.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Monsieur Coopee a word with you.

div.stage: [Prat goes aside and makes motions as if dancing.

sp.speaker: Semibr
sp.p: Here comes the t'other Romp that I told ye was so fond of me, I have hopes of getting her, for they say she's a swinging fortune.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Which on my Conscience will be no hard matter for thee to Compass.

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: I hope so, I'l try:—

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Come Molly wipe thy eyes Child, I'le take thee away from 'em to morrow, they shall whip thee no more seriously—

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Ugh ugh ugh ugh—

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Go and ask my Lady my Wife blessing, and then come to me again, de'e hear Molly:— that's a good girl.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: This is my wife that is to be, if my Lady can bubble the old Cuckold to give consent: d'sheart [Molly goes and asks blessing and then what shall I do with it 'tis a meer Baby.

div.stage: [rises up and runs to her Father.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Fogh, my Lady Stroddle, did your Ladyship ever see such a Nauseous thing? 'tis so like the Father.

sp.speaker: L. Stroddle.
sp.p: Her face has Mr. Deputys Clumsie Cut indeed Madam:

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: All dis, Monsieur Coopee I can shew you in less time den one half hour— tah tah— I have two tre hundre of de most admirable French step— hark you me I will tell a you in four words.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: Four words Sir, you hove spoke above four thousand in less than a minute. I can hear no more, I must beg your pardon, I must go teach.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Monsieur Merriton, did you ever see such a dam English Puppy? I tell you vat Sir:

sp.speaker: Y. Merriton.
sp.p: And briefly too, Sir or else—

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: And did the Governess whip her, say ye Sir? Why this is barbarous, but yet I see she's pretty brisk for all her Jerking.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Brisk, nay, the Girl is mettle to the back seriously, but I'le take her away to Morrow I'me resolv'd, they shall jerk no Child of mine, if it must be done, I'le have the jerking her my self.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Well said Mr. Deputy, 'ds ' heart what a thing of a Spouse shall I have?

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Oh here's dear Mr. Coopee,— Sir your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: Yours dear Misse, I have brought your Guittarr here, and harkee you'l be sure to be ready to morrow to get out as we have contriv'd

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Yes I warrant ye, and you shall see I'le do it so Cunningly.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Oh Ienny has got her Guittarr, pray look upon her, Madam, there's an Ayre, there's a shape, there's an Ingenious look, fogh t'other awker'd Romp makes me sick.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: De deevil take a me if in the space of half an hour Monsieur Merriton, I would not have tell a dat Ignorant English Puppy all dis, and hark you I vill tell you one ting more—

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: No more Monsieur, not a word upon my faith, I am almost deaf already, besides I must see the Dance.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Dis is ver strange dey vill no hear me speak begar.

div.stage: Here the Romps perform a Ridiculous Dance with Guittarrs out of Tune.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Very fine, upon my honour, those Guittarrs agree with the dance admirably— hold up your head Ienny.

sp.speaker: L. Stroddle.
sp.p: And gives 'em a delicate Ayre, Madam, oh 'tis extream fine.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: The Divil it is, gad a half-tub Strung with Packthread is better Musick by half.

div.stage: Enter Jiltal in an Indian habit, and Oyley.

sp.speaker: Le. Prat.
sp.p: Zoon who is dis I see my dear Sweet pret Metresse Betty in disguise, I must know vat dis mean

sp.speaker: Y. Meriton.
sp.p: Oh yonder's the Sham-Indian Heiress the Rogue Amorous I see has drest her rarely.

div.stage: [Then the Scene shuts out the rest.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Iernie Metresse Oyley you ravish me to tell me dat your Lady came in disguise to entertain me.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: 'Tis most Certainly so Sir, you are most extreamly in her favour, this was a fit of Jealousie in her to find what Lady you hanker'd after:— I find the Fool has money now.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Jealousy begar is as true a sign of Love as huffing is of Cowardice, ah garzoon I languish, I dye, for her, dear Metresse Oyley can you tink I may Enter de fort of her favour for one hundred Guinny.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: A 100. Guinnys, ay, any fort in Christendom Monsieur assure your self.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Begar here dey are den but where, how shall I kiss her fair hand Dear Sweet Charming Metresse Oyley.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: The Frenchmans as hot as if he were Bombing a fort in good Earnest— well, have patience a little Monsieur, and by and by— I'le bring you a Note—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Aw I understand a you— mum—

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: The Captain has a great many taking Qualities I perceive Madam; Pray Sir what Country-man are ye?

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: If I should speak truth now, and tell her my Mother was a Sinderwench, and that I was whelp'd in the Mews Dunghil, how my Lady will be surpriz'd [Aside.] Madam, my Native Country was Arabia Foelix, my Father was a very near Relation to Prester Iohn, The Bouncers of Affrica are the Ancient'st Family in the World, Madam, for my own part thirsting after Glory, I left my Country to assist at the late memorable Seige of Buda, where I stood upon the Breach just by the Governour at the Storming of the Town, I saw him fall, and narrowly Scap'd my self; after which action acquainting my self with a famous English Officer, one Collonel Bragg, I came over hither, where I soon learnt the Language, and had the honour to Ingratiate my self with her most noble Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Oh dat is certain de Bounsers be ver great Family in France too.

div.stage: [Oyley comes and gives Le Prat. a Note in an Orange.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: The Lyers indeed are a great Family all the World over, now rather then not prate at all with that French Fool, joyn with 'tother in his monstrous vanity.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: If he's neither Singing, Dancing, nor Prating, you may conclude a French Man dead at any time.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Oh Cozen, as I was standing at the door, just now, who should come by but that old sawcy Granadeer who had the Impudence to affront ye so yesterday, I told him you are within here, and that you would have him whip'd, and seriously, what does the old Rascal do but gave me a huge Box o'th Ear, call'd you a Thousand Sons of Whores, kickt Molly; beat two of my Lady's Footmen that took my part, and is just now forcing his way in hither seriously, o Lord!

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: D'shert what shall I do, this is my old dog of a Father, now shall I be disgrac'd for ever.

div.stage: Enter Old Bragg fighting with two Footmen. Y. Merriton, and Le Prate part 'em.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Jernie— vat is de meaning of dis sa, sa, vat a Plague do you do.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Let me go and I'le beat the Rogues into Paste.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Whats the matter Friend?

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Oh are you there Sirrah? [runs to Y. Brag. what you threaten to have me Whipt de'e, you Prodigal Son of a Whore— harkee dogbolt, who am I? hah!

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: The Devil, I think, I'me sure y'are as great a plague to me, [Aside. I must face him down with Impudence; there's no way else— what art thou mad old fellow? who wouldst thou speak with? ha!

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Mad old fellow, here's an Impudent Rascal, what you have forgot me Rogue, have ye? but I'le rub up your Memory presently:—

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Why how now old Armour of proof de'e know to whom you give this Language, the Gentleman's a Captain.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Why let him be a Collonel, he's my Son, and I'le call him as many Rogues and Rascals as I please.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Would I had been the Son of a Coach-horse.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Thy Son, ha ha ha, this is pleasant i'faith; art thou the stock of the Ancient family of the Bouncers of Affrica ha ha ha ha ha.—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: De fellow has not bin bred in France dat I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Hark'e Sir, I'm Courting a young Lady here that has six thousand pound Fortune, follow my directions, and recover my Credit, and you shall have half.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Six Thousand Pounds—

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Every Farthing Sir; 'tis she yonder that stands by the old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: And shall I have half, Neddey?

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: You shall; therefore own your self to be Colonel Brag, an Acquaintance of mine at the Siege of Buda, and let me alone for the rest.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Why, this is fair now Neddy? now you don't abuse and slight your old Father, you are a good Boy— Three Thousand Pounds! Gad Zooks! 'tis enough to make me a Colonel indeed.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Mind your Cue; Ha, ha, ha, ha: Come dear Colonel, 'tis enough now, prithee leave off thy Joking, I see my Lady is surprized at it. Why, Madam, and Gentlemen, this was nothing but a Jest all this while, this is my dear Friend Colonel Brag that I met withal at Buda—

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I am Colonel Brag, and as the Captain says, we me together at Buda.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Methinks your Habit is not very like a Colonel, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Prat.
sp.p: Jernie de ver, resemblance of de English nasty foot Granadeer.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Oh, a Jest, a Jest, the Colonel has often these Frolicks to come a broad in a Disguise; he has some Design in this now I warrant.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: I warrant he is a Colonel o'th wrong side, by his beating my Footmen; the Rebels all know my Livery, and have a spite at it; and therefore pray tell him, Cozen, I care not for such Roysters Company.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Sir, you'd do well to humour my Lady a little in her way, she's a great Stickler against the Government.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: What, you'd have me speak Treason, would you ye Rogue, and so hoist my self to the Gallows before I'm aware.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Would thou wert hoisted there fifty Cubits high: Dsheart, this old Scoundrel will discover all yet, I see by his awkward Carriage.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: A Filthy Beast! Come, Madam, let's leave him, and go and give order for our Bonfire. Madam, are your Ladyship's Jack-Boots ready.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: They were liquor'd this Morning, Madam; I'm ready in a Minute.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Mr. Alderman, Come, let's go; Cozen Bouncer, come you away too from the Old Rebel, I have occasion to use ye.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: I'le wait on ye, Madam. Meet me at the Magpy-Tavern at Nine.

div.stage: [Exeunt L. Addle. L. Strod. Thrum. Y. Brag.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Enough, I'le come— Gentlemen, Good buy.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, your Servant good Colonel Musquet, ha, ha, ha, I will know the bottom of this Cheat I'm resolv'd, and to effect it thou shalt go and invite 'em to a Glass of Wine with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: That old fellow is certainly a Counterfeit; but what is t'other? Is he really a Captain?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p:
No more than thou art a General: 'Tis the Common Title now-a-days
for all the Bullies, Shop-lifts, Robbers, Pimps, Panders and Rakehels about the Town; any tall Fellow that can but get a red Coat on's Back is dubb'd a Captain presently: But prithee let's go, whilst the Monsieur is busie yonder, for fear he should thrust himself upon us; and dear Rogue, procure me but another Meeting to Morrow with Mirtilla, and then I'm thine for ever.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: I'le do what I can, but you may thank your Dancing Faculty.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Jernie, heer be de very pret Fancy, a Sheny Orange vid de Billet Doux wrap in it; ha, ha, ha, let a me see now vat it say? Ha!— 'Tis from my deer sweet Mrs. Betty, Begar— I'le go into the Garden and read it, for I see here comes more Company.

div.stage: Enter Rakehel, Amorous, and Jiltall, in a Rage.

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: Patience! Talk not to me of Patience, Mr. Amorous, I will have Justice.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: You shall, Madam, you shall.

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: I'le have him hang'd, I'le make a Parliament business of it, I'le make him an Example to all Villanous cheating Guardians; I'le mount him, tho it cost me half the Estate.

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: This is a very Indian Devil.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: 'Tis well she's ignorant who you are, Sir; for she has such a Devillish Spirit, that, Gad, if she knew, she'd go near to tare ye to pieces.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: The very Issue of a Dragon; Gadzooks, I'm afraid to come near her.

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: Would I had the Villain here ' I'd tare his Throat out with these Fingers, I'de chop him into more pieces than ever Medaea did her Brother Absirtus in Story: What say you, Sir? would not you help me to murder the Villain, hah—

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: O yes, Madam,; I'd have a Leg or an Arm of the Rascal if he were here

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: A Treacherous bloody kidnabbing Villain, hah, Sir!

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: Oh, a Rogue, a Rogue, a very Rogue!

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: Oh that this Dagger were in his Hearts Blood.

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: He were right serv'd if it were, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: But the Gallows shall perform the Work more decently; therefore Mr. Amorous, if you have any Love for me, as you profess, lose not a minut's time in the Prosecution; you know the Witnesses are all ready, and want nothing but a Summons; I think the Law cannot fail to do me right in so notorious an Abuse; but if it should, I swear by Mars, Apollo, Venus, Mercury, and all the Powers of Fire, Air, Earth and Water, rather than let my Cause be left in the Lurch, I'le stab him, tho I do it in the Church.

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: Ay, there I would give thee leave, for I never come into one; but that's all one on my Conscience, this Fury will be the Death of me one way or other.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir; For to say Truth, she has often a mad Fit takes her, and then she fears neither God, Man, nor the Devil; she got it with drinking Brandies and Hot Waters in the Indies, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: Well Cozen, I see I must depend upon thee— What relief, hah?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, to shew what a Value I have for ye, and what Care for your Reputation, make up the Estate of Seven hundred a Year that I sold
ye, a Thousand, and settle it upon me, and I'll instantly marry her, and give you a Discharge for all the rest.

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: Well, well, I'le do't Nephew, I'le do't, for I find, if I should carry it against her by Law, I shall never carry my own Guts in quiet an hour after; she'll have her Dagger amongst 'em before I'm aware.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ay Sir, besides the Disgrace of Kidnapping you know.

sp.speaker: Rakehel.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis time; but Mum for that, good Nephew; thou knowest all Flesh is frail, and 'twas a shrewd Temptation: Go, go, and get the Writings ready, and I'le Seal to Morrow: But prithee when thou hast Married her, keep her within doors, for Gadzooks, I had rather eat a Fricassy of Souls with Belzebub, than meet her in my Dish again.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha— Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: And most damnably frighted, what betwixt the shame of being taken for a Kidnapper, and his own Cowardly Apprehensions of being Murdered, he's e'en out of his Wits; the business is done, ye little Devil, the Writings are going to be drawn for a Thousand a Year, and he's to Seal to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Iiltal.
sp.p: Ah, dear Dog, I am glad on't for thy sake, I vads Iacky; and I think I acted to the Life.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Rarely, Rarely, and thy Settlement shall fare ne're the worse for't; it may chance to swell to Five Hundred a year now, ye dear Devil you.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: No indeed sweet Blood, that's too much I'm afraid, you'l think I'm mercenary, Iacky; Mrs. Strikeup, Sir Thomas Rental's Mistress, 'tis true, has Five Hundred a year; but for my part, my dear Honey, sweet Puppy-face, thou art so Charming I can love thee without e're a Groat.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ah! dear Betty, I love thee so entirely, that I think I can never do enough for thee: Prithee let's go and be private a little, shall we?

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Not now, dear Iacky, there's the Governess and some other Boarders in my Chamber, who expect me at supper, but to morrow my Honny-suckle Rogue I'le be thine all day— till when my little dear sweet Apes Face, adien— Ah Sirrah, I'm too fond of thee.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, if all thy Charming Sex had Souls like thee despising base Confinement and wore thy constant kind endearing humour, in what a forlorn state were Matrimony! A Wife! why is not she the best of Wives, that loves me, that pleases and indulges my desires, and all still upon honour, without force, and this, dear Betty, is thy Character.
sp.l: Marriage the product of Convenience is,
'Tis Love with freedom brings the truest Bliss.

div.stage: Enter Le Prat from the Garden.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: How now, what makes this French Puppy here grinning? so Monsieur, you are very merry, I see.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Merry! ay begar, I have de ver good reason too if you knew all— dis Lettra dat you see here make me de most happy person in de whole World, begar.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: A Letter! what from some young thing here I warrant, that's smitten with thy airy parts; come prithee— discover thou knowest I am thy Friend, art stealing a Fortune here? hah—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Dam Fortune, she's a blind Bawd dat obliges none, but Fool begar; dis Intreague is beyond all de Fortune in de World, which because you are de Man of Honour I will communicate; you must know den dat here is great Beauty in dis-Town dat goes by the name of Madam Iiltal.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ha, Iiltal!—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: A rare Creature, both for de Shape, de Wit, de Beauty, and every ting dat is incomparable.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: So, Sir.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Now you must know dat at intreaguing is de very soul of the French, and my self being always great Admirer of dat Gallantry, I have endear my merit so much in her Favour, by de Song, de Fiddle, de Present, and oder ting shall be nameless, dat she came yesterday hither in an Indian habit to meet me.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: To meet you—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Yes, begar, ha, ha, ha, vas not ver pretty frolick, hah, for you must know dat we have sometime met together in order place before now.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Damnation! What does this Rascal mean [Aside.] This must be my Betty, it can be no other— So, Sir, and that Letter is from her, is it?

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Just now sent to invite me to her private Chamber, where dere is de Bed, and Couch, and Chair, and all oder convenience; ah, 'tis full of de most tender obliging expression dat ever vas writ; dere, read, you shall find she has great deal of Wit— she's ver fine person, ma foy.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Hell take me if it be not her own Character! Oh patience!

q.p: Your Merits, dear Sir, have so won upon my heart that I can no longer defer your desire; therefore you may come, if you please, by the Back Garden up Stairs into my Apartment; for I'm oblig'd to stay here to night upon some urgent occasion; now is your time, and to endear ye more, know that I intend to feign my self sick to a young passionate Fool that loves me and waits for admittance, to possess the greater Pleasure of enjoying your sweet Company.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ay, dat Fool, dat Fool, de turning away of dat fool dat wait, please me most of all— ha, ha, ha, vat tink you? Hah, is not she an Angel?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: A down right Devil.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Deevle! who, who, Jernie, vat are you tinking on? Oh you are surprised at her Wit are you? ha, ha, ha, vel begar, I believe she has the richest brain in all England, ma foy, and is assurement the greatest.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Jilt in Europe, by Heaven! Oh— Confound her, is all [Stamps the Vows and fondness come to this— Ah dear Merriton now I confess my Blindness and thy Judgment.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Hey! Vat a Diable is de matra? nay, nay, if you be mad, come give me de Lettra, and let me go, for I long to be embracing de dear, dear ravishing Creature dat stay for me.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why then let me tell you, Monsieur Rantipol tanto, you shall not have her Letter, nor shall you go to her neither.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Hey morbleau, vat time of the Moon is dis,— vat you mean Monsieur!

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why I mean to signifie to ye Monsieur, that this Charming Angel of yours has been my Whore this seven years; I settled an Estate upon her in 87, carried her to Flanders in 88, and spent two thousand pounds upon her in 89, brought her over with me in 90, and now this present year find my self jilted and resolve a Revenge, therefore consent to quit all pretensions to her instantly or draw.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Draw, dis is very fine begar, I come heeder to make Love, and you will force me to make War, but it never shall be say dat a Frenchman desert his Mistress, or his Intreague— Come on Monsieur, sa, sa.

div.stage: [Leaps backward, and fences at a distance.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: A Plague, what you are dancing a Galliard, are ye— Come, I'le shew ye an English step, Sir,

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Gazoon, vat dam Fortune is dis? I have shame my Country— begar dis is de first time dat ever de French were foil'd.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are ill read in History I find; come, there's your Sword agen, you see I scorn to make you beg your Life; therefore in return of Honour, fail not to meet me here to morrow at this time; I have business with ye—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Begar, you are ver brave Fellow, therefore I'le come; and dee hear Monsieur, when ever our great Monarch come and conquer your Country, de Devil take a me, but I will do as much for you.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh, I thank ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Dis is ver brave Fellow, ma foy, but a Plague of his dam English step for all dat.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.l: And now to ruminate on my Revenge,
And right my self in this strange turn of Fortune;
For oh, I lov'd this Jilt beyond my Reason,
Wounded my heart afresh, and every night
Fancied I had the first sweet budding Nosegay,
When every Flower was common in the Market.
Suppose I poison, or I strangle her,
Why, I send her to th' Devil, my self to th' Gallows.
sp.p: What satisfaction! Suppose I trade with some of her Aunts the Bawds, and get the Pox, and give it her, why then the Venom of her own Nature will relieve it, and I alone am wretched, or should I cut her into little Morsels, like a true Serpent, every part would live, and every part would joyn agen to sting me. No, I have it, the Purse is the Whores mortal part, I'll stab her there.
sp.l: Learn this by me, you that desert kind Wives,
And with this cursed Tribe debauch your Lives;
For Gold you gain a thousand Sweets and Dears,
But cease to pay, and then the Punk appears.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT. IV. Scene I. A Tavern.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: TO laugh at thee is not like a Friend, and to rail at her would be to no purpose: I only hope thou wilt value my Judgment another time, and in the present Juncture make a good use of this lucky discovery.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: I warrant thee, thou shalt as much value me for my discretion now, as thou didst formerly wonder at me for my strange stupidity, but yet by Heaven it shocks my very Nature to think such barbarous ingratitude could injure such true Love.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p:
That Love was rather a Disease in thee than otherwise; thou
hadst a Callenture, and thy strange madness muffled her jilting mischiefs from thy Eyes.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Damn'd Mercenary Whore.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh fie! How canst thou rail at a poor Creature for acting of her kind. A Whore and Jilt are Boot and Spur, the one depends on t'other, and 'tis unreasonable to expect a separation; and if thou thinkest thy Wit or Love could make her constant, thou art weaker still; for a Whore has no Love but what depends on Appetite; the coursest Food often goes down the best, and is just like one invited to an excellent Treat, yet is not satisfied, nor thinks himself well entertained, unless after all you let him take a nasty Pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Drawer within.
sp.p: Half a Flask in the King's Arms, Score.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.l: How near the cursed Nature of the Devil is such a nauseous Creature?
Yet such there are I find.
Sir, there's a Gentleman below desires to speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.l: Oh, 'tis Coopee; go and send him up, Sirrah.
I employ'd him, Iack, about a pleasant Discovery of the Colonel and Captain
I told thee of— Well, what now Tom?

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: They are coming, Sir; and 'twill make you laugh to see in what a strange Romantick Dress the old sham-Colonel's in now; he looks just like the old Picture of Giddeon in the Hangings, and struts as if he were newly come from lapping at the River.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: I'me resolved to find out the Trick now; and if thou canst get the Romp and the Six Thousand Pounds, thou dost thy self a Profit, me a Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: What, the Rogue is stealing one of the Kitlins from the Boarding-School, is he?

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I think you have nicked it, for all she can do yet is to Purr and Mew a little, she is not come to her Scratching. But there has a plaguy Accident hapned since I saw you last.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: What, Prithee? a discovery of any thing?

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: All, all, Faith; and the business is this moment in Agitation; that damn'd Witch Crowstich has told the Governess that I used to cram the Girl with Almonds and Reasons, and when I taught her to Dance, kiss her between every Step, upon which Mr. Deputy and my Lady are sent for this Afternoon; for my part, I was discarded presently: but to shew ye that I have play'd my Game very well, just as I was going out of Door, the poor young Fool follow'd, and pretending to give me a Song-Book, pinn'd this Note to the first leafe, ha, ha, ha— Here, you may read it if you can, for she does but just scrawl, and spells worse than a Town-Whore in a Billet-doux.

q.p: If you lofe me as you portend, and will marro me, and let me go abroad to eat Cowsturd and Chesscock as often as I please, I will lofe you butter than my Father, and will come to you out at the Balcondey in the Iurdain at Eight a Clock just after we have Soopt. I am, sweet Mr. Coopee, your true Friend, Jenny Addleplot. Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha. One that never knew it, might Swear that Letter came from a Boarding-School by the Lofe and Butter that's in't.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: So, why this goes very well, hah, and thou intendest to be at the Balconey at the time appointed, do'st not.

sp.speaker: Coopee.
sp.p: Most punctually: For I hear my Lady intends to match her to this Coxcombly Captain that's coming hither, but I'le prevent her Faith, I'le about it instantly.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, here comes the Colonel— Now for the Discovery.

div.stage: Enter O. Brag. ridiculously dress'd like an Antick Officer, and Y. Brag. with him.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Now, Sir, besure you don't discredit your self, but remember you are a Colonel still.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your Tongue, and leave off your sawcy Instructions or as I am a true Grauadeer—

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Or Lord, O Lord, a Granadeer already!

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: A true Colonel I mean, Sirrah, I will swinge you incessantly.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh Colonel, your most humble Servant, and Captain yours;— Pray know my Friend here.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am your Worm to tread upon, the Lappet of your Shooe, your Slave of Slaves, and shall be proud to serve you, whether in the Celler, the Kitchen, or the Stable.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: So now he talks like a Groom, a Tapster, and Scullion— I shall be undone.

sp.speaker: Y Mer.
sp.p: Oh, you debase your self too much, Colonel, for so great an Officer, performing such an Action as yours at the Siege of Buda qualifies ye to be a General to some great Monarch.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Pray, Colonel how is their Method of Fortification at Buda?

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Buda, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ah, he's foundred already: Dsheart; Sir, own you have an ill Memory presently, or you'll spoil all.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: I've a very ill Memory Gentlemen, I hope you'll excuse me.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Tell 'em you hurt your Brain by catching a great Cold with lying in the Winter-Trenches in Hungary.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Why, when was I in Hungary, Sirrah? This Rogue crams so many Lies into my Mouth together, that Gadzooks, 'tis a pain to me to know which I shall get out first.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: You must needs be able to give a good Account of the famous Transaction at Buda, Sir: Come, pray let's hear.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Say yes, yes Sir, and I'le help ye out.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Yes, yes Sir, at least the Captain here can, if I can't. Go and manage your Lie your self, ye Dog, I'm almost choak'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: We were both drawn out, Gentlemen, in the Detatchment that receiv'd the Assault; the Colonel here, I must needs say, behav'd himself more like a Lion than a Man. And for my own part, I scap'd by Miracle; I fought on Foot three Hours by the Clock, when above twelve Great Field-Pieces play'd at me all the while as thick as Hail; I had the Honour to Horse the King of Poland twice, lent my own Sword to the Duke of Bavaria when he was in Distress; and at last, with a Clapper of a Bell, which a swinging Turk that I had just before kill'd, had us'd instead of a Battle-Ax, fought through their Vantguard, and came off safe in spite of 'em.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: A Clapper of a Bell! Why Captain, there are no Bells in Turkey.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: No, Captain, no— The Turks never use any Bells or Clappers neither.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ah plague of my heedless Nonsense, what shall I say now.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p:
Hold ye, Gentlemen, hold ye, I can make it out plain: Now will
I help the Rogue off at a dead list.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: What, that the Turks use Bells, Colonel Coddlebrain.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: The Turks, No, no: But you must know that the Captain there was formerly Prentice to a Black-smith, and brought the Clapper to the Wars along with him.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, that may be indeed— Your Servant, Noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Much Good may'● do ye with your Clapper, worthy Captain.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ah, Pox of your Plain-dealing— I'm disgrac'd for ever now: What do you mean by this Colonel, when was I Prentice to a Black-smith, hah!

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: When? Why, what a damn'd shallow Brain hast thou: Why, wert not thou Prentice to Old George Grimble when I sold Brandy and Tobacco by the Church-wall at Antwerp, just the Winter before I listed my self a Granadeer.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: A Granadeer!

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ah the Devil! now all's out, and nothing can retrieve it.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: No, no, a Granadeer: He listed himself a Colonel, I warrant; hah— what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Ay, a very fine Story you have made of this indeed, and I shall inform my Lady presently of your great Merit and Extraction; and so my most Noble Black-smith Adien.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Your Servant, honest Granadeer.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, tho' the Captain here be a kind of a Coward, or so, yet you shall know that I have a Sword.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: And Dagger, I know it; all Granadeers have. Come, come, 'tis in vain to be testy with us; there's Mony for the Wine, you can't do less than drink together when we are gone— Hush, not a word more.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: O. Brag. and Y. Brag. stare at each other.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ah! plague of your Antwerp Occupation, here's 6000 l. lost now, and the best Maintenance that ever Man had: Oh, I'm lost, ruin'd for ever! I shall never be kept again, that touches the very Soul of me: Oh! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Why, take your Turkish Battle-Ax, and go to the Wars, Captain, you'l get Immortal Honour I know presently; and so here's my Service to ye, good Captain Clapper.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Nay, let it be some of the Brandy then that you sold by the Church wall, good Colonel Granadeer: D'sheart, was the Devil in ye to talk at that Rate?

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: What, Sirrah, I warrant you thought I had cramm'd a dozen or two of Lies in the hinder part of my Jaw, as a Monkey does the overplus of his Dinner. But, Sirrah, I'd have you know I was of too honest a Principle.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Honest! Ay, that's it has made ye dine so often on pickled Herrings and hard Cheese; Oh, what will become of me?

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Come, come, Sirrah, take the Gentleman's Advice, and strip from that fluttering Coat, and sell it, 'twill serve to make us merry a considerable while; and since these Titular Captains are most of 'em Rogues, I'le provide you a new Title, you shall serve the King and Queen, Sirrah, and be as I am, an honest Granadeer.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p:
Lord, Sir, what do you mean? If my Lady should but hear I was in
Company where they but named the King and Queen, she would discard me for ever— And I have yet some small Hopes.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'le have you hope no more hopes; but let my Lady be pox'd by her whole Party, cramp'd with her Jack-boots, and choak'd with her cold Tea. Come, come, strip, strip, I'le have the Coat off presently; that Lace will keep us two Months at least, in Tobacco, Brandy, and Red Herrings.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, he's at his old Play agen.

sp.speaker: O Brag.
sp.p: Come, come; quick, quick; off with Hat, Peruke, and Coat; quick, I say.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Quick! Ay, as quick as my Legs can carry me, [runs out] if you are at that sport.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Say you so, Rascal? I'le be with ye presently Faith.

div.head: SCENE II. The Boarding-School.
div.stage: Enter Mirtilla with a Book in her hand.

q.l: Embarqu'd at last, and sculk'd into the Hold;
My Flight was to my jealous Parents told;
As much too timorous they, as I too bold.
Ah dear, dear Ovid, how thy precious Wit,
Drest in the glittering Robe of Charming Poetry,
Moves my soft Soul?— When e're thou writest of Love,
Methinks my Heart melts with the Sacred Flame,
And even makes Virgin Innocence grow wanton:
For then dear Merriton I think on thee,
And every Thought begets an Extasie,
Almost too fierce for Vertue to endure:
Yet tho' I love thee, my Resolves are constant,
I'le sigh and mourn for thee my dearest Friend,
But can no more, till our hard Fortunes mend.

div.stage: Enter Lady Addleplot, Crowstich, and L. Stroddle.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: You amaze me, Mrs. Crowstich, with this Discovery: I thought it impossible the Girl should be so wild.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: 'Tis strange indeed, Madam, for one of her years; but your Ladiship shall have the proof on't presently.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: She here! To disturb my Contemplation: Horrid Creature! How shall I avoid her?

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: The t'other Dowdy indeed I always imagin'd indocible; but that Sir Arthur's Offspring, a Child born of my own Body, Bone of my Bone, Flesh of my Flesh, Vitals of my Vitals, that she should degenerate, I am amaz'd at it!

sp.speaker: L. Strod
sp.p: To look so much below her self, as to fancy a little Dancing-Master; 'tis not adequate your Ladyships Blood that runs in her, I confess.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Whither were you going you great Romp? ha!

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Oh Pray Mam forgive me this time, and I'le never do so agen.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Only to Mr. Coopee, Madam; this has been hatching a good while; the t'other too is as mad for Semibrief our Singing-Master; they were both found Romping in the Garden with 'em last Night, but the Governess has turn'd them away for't. Here she comes with her Father, I've told him her Tricks already.

sp.speaker: Nicomp.
sp.p: Ah Madam, the Girls are both undone seriously!

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: The Girls! I hope you don't couple your Tarrier there with Sir Arthur's Breed, Jack Sawce!— Ah Tearshift, 'tis evident now that filthy thing there has quite spoil'd Miss by Keeping her Company.

sp.speaker: Tear.
sp.p: 'Tis certainly so, Madam, there's no comparison between the Childrens Parts.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: I'lle examine her my self. Hussey, speak the Truth, and scape the Rod: What did you and that aukward Creature do with Coopee and Semibrief in the Garden last Night?

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: No hurt, truly, truly now.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: What business had ye there? What was your Design? Come, don't ye lie.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Why, we Eat, ugh, ugh; we eat a dozen of Custards there.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: A dozen of Custards, very well.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: And about Fourteen Cheescakes.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: There wan't Fourteen then, there was but Thirteen in all, and I have one of them in my Pocket here.

div.stage: [Pulls out a great Cheescake, and eats it.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: My Lady Stroddle, did ye ever hear such a filthy Romp?

sp.speaker: L. Stroddle.
sp.p: She has a little too much of the vulgar, I confess, Madam.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Madam, I beseech your Ladyship to hear Molly tell what Words pass'd between 'em, and what that Impudent Singing-master said to her.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Pray Madam, let me beg your Ladyship. Come Molly, leave chawing your Cheescake, and tell my Lady, Child.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Why, he ask'd me—

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: But pray Mother don't be angry with Mr. Coopee, for he's a mighty pretty Man, and the best Caperer in all the Town.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: And pray Father don't fall out with Mr Semibrief, for he's a fine Man every inch of him, and the best Triller, aw, aw, au, au.

sp.speaker: Nicomp.
sp.p: The poor Fool wins upon me so with her pretty Carriage, that seriously I can deny her nothing: Come and kiss me, Molly.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Fogh, how the Brute licks the Calf yonder. Well, Mrs. Crowstich, tho' the Fellow has been sawcy with her; 'tis not so far gone I see, but the Girl may be reclaimed.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Ah Madam, this is not half her Fault; if this had been all I had born it with some Patience; but, Madam, he has taught her to be a Rebel too.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: And made 'em drink Confusion to the French three times one after another in Sillabub.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Degenerate Bastard? Is't possible! I had rather she had been choak'd.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Nay, and what's worst of all, the Villan made her sit on's Knee and sing an impudent Ballad twice over in praise of King William.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: A young Whore, gad I'll whip her presently before ye all.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Nay, dear Lady, seriously, you'll put your self into such an heat.— Hussy get ye gone

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: I've a trick for't yet, for I'll go and hide my self till night, and then get out to Mr. Coopee at the Belcony.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: And I'll get out at the Cellar-Window to Mr. Semibrief and be gone from 'em all I'm resolv'd on't.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Away ye Coxcomb, or I'll give you as much; 'dslife a young Jade to drink Confusion to the French; I shall hate Sillabub as long as I live for't; but I'll claw her, I'll teach her to turn Rebel.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. Crowstich go and strive to pacifie her, for she is in a devillish humour seriously.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: But to pass upon 'em thus for a dancing Master and undiscovered, is a strange Riddle to me.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: It pleased Mrs. Crowstich to introduce me, who it seems, has some friendly opinion of my qualification for my performance Yesterday; beside, what can be strange to Love, who'd not change Shapes like Iove for such a Danae?

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Who wou'd not talk like you that had your Wit?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Or who would live confin'd here, that had yours? once more think on my Suit then dear Angel.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Nay, now you are unjust; did you not promise, provided I would suffer ye to see me, to touch no more upon that jarring string?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: If that be jarring, there is then no Musick; but Discord is the Soul of Harmony. I own I promised ye, alas! but how? as men in Fevers promise not to drink, yet have no Ease or Comfort till they break it; or as to modest Virgins newly wedded and beg a Weeks Reprieve, we seem to promise, but how can that e're bind the amorous Bridegroom, when there's necessity it should be broke?

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Little should I depend upon your promise, when you had power, that can infringe it now.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: All things of sense unanimously excuse me; I cannot look upon thee without loving, nor love thee but I must renew my suit.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: A Suit bent to the ruin of us both.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: No, rather to our Souls Eternal Comfort.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! What Comfort can there be in Love, curb'd and confin'd by Poverty?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: We have no Poverty, whilst we love enough; the Dross of gilded Luxury ne're can equal the Glittering Ore of our sublime Contentment. Thou hast a Soul I know disputes Fortune as much as vile unchastity or folly; a Soul that sits in the middle of her Wheel with Wings still poyz'd, not mounting up, nor falling, but in a constant Station fixt, canst smile at those that climb, and those that hurry down.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: I have so, and I own I think as little of the vain noisy fluttering World as you, the gawdy Fop or haughty thing of Title, the strutting Prelate, or the Knave in Furs can laugh at too; nay I could be contented with the least gift of Fate, if that were all.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: If that were all! What is there else, sweet Life?

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p:
'Tis not for my own sake that I deny, but, Sir, for yours; if we were married, perhaps I should love ye, nay love ye dearly; perhaps have Children too, some half a dozen pretty smiling Blessings to cling around and help Lifes tedious Journey with the dear nonscence of their prattling Stories. But should the freezing hand of Want afflict us, what should we do, but sit by our small fire, Tears in our Eyes and throbing Griefs at Heart, to see our little Flock of unfledg'd Cupids, shivering with Cold as wanting necessaries,
who looking wishly on us seemed to say, why would you marry thus to make us miserable?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Thou talkst of Children, and I think of Heaven, when I conceit thou art to be their Mother; oh I would learn to out-dig my Grandsire Adam, e're thou shouldst want the profits of the Earth, or my dear Children born of thy sweet Body, their due or proper sustenance.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: And what must I do then when you should dig? I know in Marriage we must share the Troubles as well as Joys of him we are confin'd to; can I see him that lies within my Arms so full of cares he has scarce time for Love, rise early to provide for me and mine, and I not knit, or sow, or spin or something? The labouring Husband that has a lazy Wife may not only suspect her Love, but Vertue— No, I'de never part from you in your ill Fortune, but will not be the Cause to bring it on ye.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: You cannot be the Cause I have enough, tho' not what you deserve.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: But I alas! have not enough for you.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: No matter, Heaven will prosper.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: That I hope, and then my Tongue shall tell another story, till when adieu; and yet I believe I value ye, and 'tis value keeps me from consenting.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Come, come, 'tis plain you hate me; for if you did not, Fortune and Wealth were Trifles.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Be ungrateful and think so still.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: I must and will by Heaven!

div.stage: [Is going out, and Old Merriton meets him.

sp.speaker: O Mer.
sp.p: How now Son? Why in such hast? Come back agen.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: My Foster Father here, and in this unhappy Juncture! Oh Heaven! What shall I say to excuse my self?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech ye give me leave, I'm ill o'th' suddain, and want a little Air— What makes he here? She said indeed she was beholding to him, but how, Heaven knows: I'le observe more hereafter, this may be a Riddle worth finding out.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Sir, I am afraid I have offended you, finding me thus discoursing with your Kinsman in this suspicious manner.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: To fear implies a Guilt; I know your Vertue, and you might have spared that word; beside, he is my Son.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Your Son! Nay, then a Sisters Amity may well excuse this Freedom; 'twas Sir, your Interest first that introduced him; for any Blood of yours meer Gratitude would prompt my throbing Heart to love and honour.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: 'Twas warm discourse you had, the purple Signal that yet remains displayed within your Cheeks, confirmed me that your Tongues have had a Battle, and Love or War has fiercely been denounced.— Pray let me know, and if I've interest in ye, as for past Cares I cannot doubt I have, give me a share in the discovery.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Sir, I dare trust you with my secret Sins, much more then with my little worldly Business: Know then, your Son has oft been pleased to honour me with passionate Expressions of his Love.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: I thought so, pray proceed

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Ah! then take all; I own I love him too, and now you have a secret out, which nothing but your Commands could ever have forced from me; I love him, Sir, yet knowing my Condition, modest regard of wronging him hereafter by my ill Stars, made my poor famished Heart hold out, though within one short hour of starving

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: This is as I could wish— Come be not sad, the Stars have better aspects than you think, and Fortunes giddy Wheel will soon turn round to sea● thee on the utmost Spoke with Honours.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Ah, do not mock my Wretchedness, dear Father!

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: Not for the World; come in with me and listen, for I will tell thee wonders; the Minute is near and the blest Hand of Providence to pass thee from thy Labyrinth of Misfortunes holds out a Clue and guides thee on to Happiness.
sp.l: In every Life, the Doom of Fate secures
One Hour to make it blest, and this is yours.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Now Monsieur, you see what a Precipice I free'd ye from, and what Reasons I had for my late passionate resentment.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Monsieur, you have made it out dat you have de good reason, and I perceive dat she be de ver dam Jilt, ma foy; and tho I have lost de little Honour in de quarrel, I have save one hundred Guinea morbleau, vish make me ver much amends: But Monsieur, pray observe, I vill shew you the finest French Song here dat I learnt dis Morning,— thol loll, loll.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: 'Dslife, no Song now, dear Le Prat, this is our very Minute of Projection; I've just sent for her, go, go, prithee step into that Closet, and when I call, come and confront her.

sp.speaker: Le. Prat.
sp.p: Vid all my Heart, and I will practise dis Song all de while dere for fear I should fall asleep.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.l: And if there be a subtiler Devil than ordinary,
Used by grave Statesmen, or by jilting Whores,
Him I invoke t'assist me; here she comes.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Why that French Fop should fail to come to my Assignation is a Riddle to me, Oyley.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: And to me too, Madam. I'm sure I wound him upright, I wonder he did not strike.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Hush, here's th'other Woodcock just faln into the Plash; one at a Shoot must serve, when there's but little Game: my dear, dear Iackey.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh my sweet, sweet, sweet— Devil!

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: But why is my dear Hony, little Puppy-dog come before the hour? hah—

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: My dear Life might assure her self, 'twas to do her good; to be short then, you must know that my Uncle just now sent for me.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: So, dear Monkey, so, so.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: And sent me word: that upon condition, that I would marry thee to morrow morning, he would feal my Settlement to Night, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, an old Fool, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha— I must laugh too, but 'tis at him; Lord, who would be a Man, to let a Woman abuse him thus?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: So dear Betty, thou knowest I had no reason to defer it, Child there's a thousand pound a year coming, ye dear, sweet, pretty, melting, charming— confounded—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I shall bite ye, Sirrah, I cannot forbear, I shall bite your Nose off If you come near me: ah Iackey, Iackey, if ever you should leave me I should dye, I should dye.—

div.stage: [Squeaks in a strange tone, and clings to him.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ah! how the Devil has turn'd her to do mischief; her trebble Violin is just now strung, and every Fop that plays upon't is damn'd,

div.stage: Le Prat. within. [Sings aloud Thol, loll, loll, and a bit of a French Song.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: How now? What's that?

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: The Devil sure, it can be nothing else.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: A Plague on him! Now is that French Fool's Head so full of that new Song, he has forgot where he is, and is singing our aloud. You need not go Mrs. Oyley, 'tis one without that came with me to be Witness to the Marriage upon occasion, or so.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I vow, I was terribly frighted at the sound; I don't use to hear any Man's Voice, but thine Iackey, so near my Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Kind Betty,— No, a Pox take ye, I find they all us'd to come in.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: There's an Oagle now, there's an Oagle, as well worth two Guineas between Turk and Jew, as one shilling's worth another.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: And will you marry me to morrow morning then Iackey?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Will I! ah thou shalt find, I'll do more for thee than that; come give Mrs. Oyley the Key, and bid her fetch the Settlement out of the Cabinet quickly, I suppose a Joynture of five hundred a year may do as well.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I can't give it her, I vow I can't, I'm ashamed,— I vow I am.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh fie! you must not trifle now, the Time wasts; Mrs. Oyley take it from her.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, since the noble Squire will have it so—

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: That Bitch takes me for a Cully too, I find by her Squiring me.— [Aside. Hast got it? go, go, make hast then.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Indeed Iacky, I shall dye for thee.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I vow I shall.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I shall never live to be brought to Bed, I'm afraid I shall have two this time— I swear, I believe I shall.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: So! here's Generation for ye! One Joynture has begot two Bastards in half a quarter of an Hour.

div.stage: Jiltal puts her Fan before her Face.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Here 'tis Sir, and Heavens bless ye for your Love to her.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Umph— I think indeed this is my erring Scrawl.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Yes indeed is it, I was witness to'r, 'tis your very hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: You are also Witness to this then,

div.stage: [Tears the Settlement. What d'ee start Bawd!

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Zoons, what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! be not afrighted I beseech ye, it may chance to make ye miscarry of your two Babes; there's what I know will please ye— 'tis your Joynture, Madam, your Ladyship understands the short-hand.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: My Letter to the Frenchman— Oh Confusion! I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: There is no Witness yet, but I'll call one; Allons Monsieur approach!

div.stage: Enter Le Prate from the Closet.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Sharming, and fair, and most extraordinary your very most humble and oblig'd Serviture; Tholl, loll—

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: D'slife, if this be true, I must into wollen stockins agen.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Madam, the Deevel take me, if I am not ver sorry— dat—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Hell take thee, burn the World, and perish Nature!

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I confess I've been your hindrance, the Monsieur had a Hundred Guineas for ye, but that I told him my Whore took no money. As for your Babes of Grace, if they chance to be born naked, and have not back and breast on like Troop, I'll give ye something to buy Blankets, and so adieu, thou Wretched—

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Impudent.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Pockey.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Common.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Senceless, and what's yet worse, Ingrateful Where, And Curse me Heaven, if e're I love thee more.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Nay, y'are right enough serv'd, could you think to have an intrigue with a Frenchman, but that all the Town shou'd know't?

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Oh! That I were a Witch now for a minute, or knew the means to be so; I've heard of Bonds written with Blood and Charms, that have by that made mischief prosperous, would some revengeful Power would tempt me once, hah!

I'me wishing for the Devil, and here he comes as pat, as he were sure to have my Soul beforehand; oh— for a Female Plot now to o'rereach this subtle Amorous, and make his Wit out-witted, the Omen appears fair, let me Consider.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: I'me sure I saw my Nephew come this way, but where to find him amongst this Warren of Conney Burrows, is a Work past my Skill; I bolted into one of their holes just now, and there were two or three young bouncing Girls stark naked, going to wash themselves in a Tub; 'gad I thought I should have lost my Eye-sight, or at least been us'd like Acteon, but that as it happen'd there were no Hounds about me. A plague on't, I can't find the way down neither, and I am damnably afraid of falling into that Indian Tygers Quarters again.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I have it, go Oyley and tell him I'de speak with him, and thou dear Devil of Female subtilty, if e're thou wert our Sexes Benefactor, assist me now.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady would speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Oh! Gad's bud, I'me fallen into the Devil's paws, with seeking to avoid 'em; Oh pray young Gentlewoman inform your Lady that the Writings are ready, I'll Seal to night, and 'tis no matter for speaking with her; alas, you know she's mad.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Mad, pray Sir, come nearer, and be undeceiv'd. Mad, did you say?

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Sir Rowland, I could ne're have thought a man of your Sense could be so grosly impos'd upon, without perceiving it.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: How's this—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you shun me as I were a Ghost, but I find this is your Nephews Trick, and I can't blame ye, he would have Trick'd me too, Sir, had I not watch'd him.

sp.speaker: Rake
sp.p: She talks well now, but if this should be a calm fit of the Devil in her, only to get time to put the Dagger into my guts, 'gad I'll keep my distance yet for all her Coaksing.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Now work but thy part Devil, we are made agen:

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I had design'd to send to ye this morning, Sir, to tell ye how this base ungrateful Fellow, this Prodigal your Nephew has abus'd ye; nay, not only you but me, by making me affront one of your merit; but, Sir, I ask you now ten thousand Pardons.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: This must be madness, for I can find no sence in it.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I had at first, 'tis true, as it was reasonable, some ill thoughts of ye, but now have much the better; his Plots are all unravell'd, and by substantial information now, I find 'twas he that fold me to the Indies.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: T'was so, Madam, oh he's a dam'd Kidnabbing wicked Fellow, 'gad I'll take heart and close in with her while the Fit lasts.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: 'Twas by his Plot I acted that mad part when last I saw ye, much against my own good nature, but I have found his Villanies out since, how he design'd to gull me to a Marriage, and you out of a Settlement; 'tis plain now, and I was sending too this very morning, to beg ye not to Seal.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Gadzooks, what's this I hear? Why hark ye, Madam, are not you really mad then?

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Mad, indeed such injuries were enough to make me so; but, Sir, I hope my Eyes will resolve that doubt; besides, if you doubt my sence, you shall hear me sing a Song of my own making.

lg.l: ROyal and Fair, Great Willy's dear Blessing,
the Charging Regent of the Swains;
Heavy with Care, thus sadly Expressing
Her grief, sat weeping on the Plains:
Why did my Fate Exalt me so high,
If fading State must deprive me of Ioy?
Since Willy is gone,
Ah! how vainly shines the Sun,
'Till Fates decree, the Winds and Sea
Waft, waft him to me.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Large are my Flocks, and flowry my Pastures,
Worth Treasures vast of Silver and Gold;
Where Ravenous Wolves too, fain would be Masters,
Devour all my Lambs, and break down my Fold:
Willy whilst here, secur'd me from fear,
All the wild Herd stood in awe of my Dear;
But poor helpless I,
Mourning Sigh, and hourly Cry
Let Fates decree, the Winds and Sea
Waft Willy to me.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: A most admirable Creature, and if I may be so bold, Madam, have you never a Dagger under your Petticoats, nor nothing?

sp.speaker: Tilt.
sp.p: Nothing that will hurt you, Sir: alass! that Dagger was given me by him to Act my part with; Oh he has abus'd us both inhumanly, but we'll be even with him now, Sir, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Shall we not? 'gad, Madam, say but a word more, and I'll have him hang'd at your door before to morrow night; here's luck, I thought I had got a Devil, ' wons 'tis a Cherubin of Cherubins.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: There's time enough to punish him, but he shall see us laugh at him first; give me your hand, will you be true to me, and revenge me on that wicked fellow?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Most vigorously—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: And take me, and my whole Fortune for your pains.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Most thankfully—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: There's Bargain made, then go and get a black Coat, I'll marry ye immediately.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: My Genius, my Soul, my Spirits, I have not breath enough to speak my joy, Oh that I could flye now, my Legs cannot carry me half fast enough, now would some honest Toping Priest would come fluttering like a Swallow down the Chimney, I must try and get one presently, for fear she cool again.
See in the World how strangely things are carried, I thought I should be hang'd, and now am to be Married.
sp.l: So now let the History my Annals grace,
Mine is the Wreath, and Matchivil's an Ass.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Three thousand Pounds a year, in three short minutes your Wit has gain'd; hah! hah! hah! ' d'slife I could leap out of my skin methinks.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Besides that poor dull wretched fellow Amorous stript out of all, in spight of all his Cunning; this now is prosperous mischief, and I am proud to see my Conquering Brain o'recome Mankind.
sp.l: Let each Miss-Keeper take this for a Rule,
to get one Young, and if he can, a Fool:
Whilst her Sence yields to his, the day's his own,
But if he's once Out-witted, he's undone.

div.head: ACT V. Scene I. Chelsey.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: WHere did you leave Sir Rowland, Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
At an Ale-House, Sir, just by the Church, waiting for Mr. Stiffrump our Parson, and he desires ye to go presently to his House, and order
his Servants to trick it up nearly, and provide a good Supper against Twelve a Clock, and then he'll come and impart t'ye an Extraordinary Affair that has happen'd to him.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: Well, go, Sirrah, and tell him it shall be done, but there [Ex. Boy. shall be other Guests there to eat it than he imagines; what he means by his extraordinary Affairs, I know not; 'tis enough for me to have brought my own so near to perfection. I have left the Lovers within, cooing like a pair of Turtles, having extreamly surpriz'd her with a discovery this Morning, that she is worth Fifty Thousand Pounds: Here she comes, so embarrass'd still between hope and fear, that she is even in pain to hear of her good Fortune— Come, come, Madam, are yet ready? Enter Young Merriton and Mirtilla. It begins to grow late.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Alas! Whither must I go? you have so surprised me with this strange News, that did I not know you to be a Man of Honour, I should believe you spoke it to abuse me.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: D'ye doubt my honesty? have I deserv'd this from ye?

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir. And pray be not angry for my diffidence; to fear is natural to our Sex; besides, Sir, fifty Thousand Pounds is such a Sum methinks!

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: As great a Sum as 'tis, you still outweigh it— And what I've said I'le justifie. Give me your hand; you must now change your Lodging, as we go on I'le tell ye more— Come, Will.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: 'SDeath, Fifty Thousand Pounds; why, 'tis worse than Witchcraft to her; half that Sum shall convert any Woman in England into a Peacock, and make her so proud of her own Tail, there would be no enduring her: I warrant she thinks now that I'll crawl on my Hands and Feet to purchase her; but she shall find she is deceived;— Love may oblige me to a slavish Duty, but Fortune never shall.

div.stage: Enter Coopee and Semibreif with a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Come, Brother Fortune-Stealer, help along with the Ladder: I hope this will prove more lucky than our last Plot; for methinks the Moon favours us very well. How goes the Night?

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: The School-Bell has just rung Nine, the Chickens within are all going to Roost, and as full I warrant of Bread and Butter, Milk, Posset, and Cawdle, as a Woman in Childbed, that has but just three days lain in.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Oh, here's the Balcony, now for the Sign.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Whose there? Coop. 'Tis I, dear Miss, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Who, Mr. Cooppe?

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: The same, the same, my dear, sweet, little, pretty—

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Oh, Law, oh, Law; but how shall I get down t'ye tho'?

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Oh, easily, easily, my dear: Look here, I've brought a Ladder for thee.

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: So, so, I see you are in a pretty posture; I'le go now and see how Affairs stand at the Cellar Window.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: A Ladder! Oh good! What, and must I act Love with a Ladder then?

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: A Ladder! you must do any thing for your poor Hubby that is to be; have you got the Packthread?

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Yes, I warrant ye; what d'ye think I would forget any thing? But will you be sure to marry me to night then?

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: To night! presently, Child, as soon as ever thou get'st off the Ladder; why, the Parson stays for thee.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: There 'tis then; I'vads he shan't stay for me; I'm better bred than so, I warrant ye.

div.stage: [Throws down the Packthread, and he ties it to the Rope.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: So, now put it round the Bar of the Window, and then let me alone to hoist it up.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: There, Oh, Gemini, what a pretty trick is this— But; dear Mr. Coopee, when we are married, what must we do afterwards, I wonder.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Afterwards; why then we must go to Bed, my Dear,

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Go to bed! well, and I'vads that will be very pretty; but what must we do after that pray, dear Mr. Coopee?

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: After that, why?—

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Ay, there's the thing now, Mr. Coopee; what must we do after that?

sp.speaker: Coop..
sp.p: Why, do but get upon the Ladder, and come down my Dear, I'le tell thee presently.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Will ye? well, and so I will I'vads; I'le be with ye in a twinkling.

div.stage: [Is getting upon the Ladder, and Crowshik comes and takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Will ye so Gentlewoman.
Pray let me have an account of your Journey first.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Oh law, what shall I do now?

div.stage: Sings.] Go, go, Friend below, I'm taken, I'm taken, Ye little Knave, get off, and save your Bacon, your Bacon.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Here are rare doings; what, you are going to be married, are ye? but I'le help yet to a Husband in the Morning. A good Rod, Hussie, that shall act Love with ye, better than the Fool below there.

sp.speaker: Miss I.
sp.p: Well, well, I will have a Husband, I'm resolv'd on't, do what you can: And if you offer to whip me, I'll tear your Eyes out, so I will.

sp.speaker: Crow.
sp.p: Go, get ye in, ye great Ramp. I'le lock her into her Sister's Room below Stairs, for to night, there's no Balcony there. ' D'slife, was there ever such a contrivance? We shall have all our Girls stole out o'th' School by Baskets full, if this trade hold; but I'le prevent it to Morrow Get ye in Hussie.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Ah, plague of my damn'd luck: If this Devil had slaid but a minute longer, I had got my Fortune upon my back, a lamping penniworth, by this time: But now, as the Devil will have it, must leave my Dow, that I have so long moulded for my own Cake, to be mumbled by the Chops of another: Pox on't, we us'd to be more prosperous in these Intreagues; and if any of these raw Tits can bolt out of their Warren at any time, 'tis ten to one but your Greyhound, Dancing-Master, or your Lurching Songster has the first snap at 'em. 'Tis a poor loving Fool, this; and o'my Conscience will be very constant to me; and if we can but contrive another Assignation, then if I lose her—

sp.speaker: Sembr.
sp.p: Hist, hist, Coopee, come along with me presently.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Phoo, prithee let me alone, I am very unfit for another Intreague now. A Pox on't, I have lost my own.

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: Ye lie, ye lie, ye Rogue; she's surer than ever; Crowshik has just now lock'd her up into a low Room, where my little Butterprint was watching for me, who as soon as ever she was gone, puts back the Lock, gets out, and they are now both together yonder at teh Cellar Window.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Ha! what dost thou say, both, what, my little Cakebread too!

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ye Dog, come quickly, and let's help 'em out.
