sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, this was beyond expectation. Run, run, run, run.

div.stage: Enter young Bragg drest like a Granadeer.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: If I had not run away from this old Dog Father of mine just now when he was drunk and fell asleep, I had been detach'd in the Morning amongst the Granadeers, and shipp'd for the Expedition in Ireland; my fine Rigging's all gone, he has damn'd, that is burnt, the very Soul of my Coat, the Lace; and my Embroyder'd Breeches hang out at a Broker's in Drury Lane; by this time, he hath taken up with the Money they yielded, a whole Firkin of Brandy, a Hogshead of Red Herrings, two dozen of Tobacco, and half a hundred of Cheshire Cheese: For my part, I believe he's turn'd Conjurer, and lays up Provision for some Famine or other that is to come. If I should appear before my Lady in this Cap, with this Cypher upon't, I were no more a Man of this world; she would fly upon me like a Cat in a Closet, and the tokens of my Manhood would be in a very desperate Condition.

div.stage: Re enter Coopee, and Semibreif, with Miss Jenny, and Molly muffled, they cross the Stage hastily.

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: Come along, along, my dear, dear little Chicken.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ha, That's Semibreif's voice; who are those with him?

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Well, you tell me you'l make me a Woman too night. But i'vads my heart goes a pitt a patt about it; for I've been told a Maid goes through a great deal of trouble before she comes to be a Woman; and if you should chance to kill me—

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: Kill thee; ha, ha, ha, never fear it, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: By Heaven, my little Boarding-School-Spouse that should ha' been.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Oh law, my Baby, my Baby— I've lost my Baby.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Ah, 'Tis no matter if thou hadst lost it, I'll get thee a better Baby my Dear.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: 'Tis so, the Romps are both stole from the School to night; and I am luckily the first discoverer. I'le dog 'em, and then run and inform my Lady; this, with some swinging lye or other may chance to re-instate me in her favour, and get me other Rigging. For to say truth, I'm damnably asham'd of this; well, Fortune prosper, I have but small hopes.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Lady Addleplott sitting, Lady Stroddle, Nicompoop arm'd back and breast, and Le Prate in Iack Boots.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: SO, so, the Rising's up, and I think we are all fitted: and since you have done me the honour to chuse me for your Colonel, you shall find me ready to push forward, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Madam, mine Horse is ready, let us go to night, begar.

sp.speaker: Le Strod.
sp.p: Methinks Mr. Deputy looks very like an Officer too.

sp.speaker: Nicom,
sp.p: Oh lack, no seriously, I make but an indifferent Figure: I profess I never wore a Sword in my life before, but once at a Training: 'Od so, I've forgot my Scaberd.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: An Officer! I vow, my Lady Stroddle, I'm asham'd of him; he'll ne're be fit for any thing but to carry the Match.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: But, Madam, I don't see the Captain here all this while.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Ah, there's another: I beseech ye, Madam, don't name him; he's found to be the greatest Rascal in Town, a poor beggerly Fellow; they say he was formerly a Black-Smith; but what has made me utterly discard him, is, the Villain has had the impudence to brag of Favours; and you know, Madam, if once they do that—

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: Ah, that's insufferable; but really he was a lusty Fellow.

div.stage: Enter Tearshift with Lady Addleplott's Rigging and Iack Boots, and a Paper in her hand.

sp.speaker: Tearsh.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, here's your Ladiships Rigging, and the account of the Kentish Rising: The Captain of the Party has sent ye the particulars.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Oh, that's good; I thought I should hear to night. Come let's peruse it, and drink their healths, hum, hum.

An Impartial Account of the Mutineers that have risen since Friday last. Very good. Imprimis. Of Officers and others, that deserted through scruple in the last Reign, and have now deserted through another scruple in this, Two Hundred and Threescore. Here's a Pint Glass, their Healths, my Lady Stroddle. Of Monks, Dominicans, Franciscan Friers, and Jesuits, that herd amongst Quakers, Fanaticks, Independents, and Fifth Monarchy Men, Fifty Nine.
Oh, fy, that's but few. L. Strod. Alas! Good Men, they have made hard shift,

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Pray observe, Madam, of Loyal Tory Rory Whores in and about London— Ten Thousand— 'Dslife, give me the Bottle.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: Ah, blessing on their Hearts. Gad 'tis pity they should have that scandalous name given 'em; the Creatures have always been very serviceable to our Party

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis certain, de Whore do ver mush good in de turn of Government: dey haunt dey haunt de Play-house, and shatt, and make a de noyce, ah, begar, they are ver serviceable.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Serviceable; ay, you'd say so if you knew all: Why, they are the chief Tools we work with; why, these Ten Thousand Whores now shall draw as many Fools to 'em in a Months time, and that will make a considerable Army. We'll be gone by break of day, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam. I'm ready at a minute. I hope we shall have Mass open again some time or other

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: A Son of a Whore to run away from his Colours, almost before he was well Listed, 'oons I'le hang him my self, I'll make him ride the Wooden-Horse twelve hours together, with a dozen of Musquets ty'd to each Leg— Let me see, this is the House I'me sure— I'll make bold to beat up her Ladyships Quarters for once, I know the Rogue is crept in here.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: See the careless Baggage, this is your leaving the door open.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: And when we are Caballing too, Oh fye Mrs. Tear-shift, this is a great fault indeed, d'slife we shall be discover'd.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Let me go my Lady Stroddle— you shall see me lay the Rascal's Soul at my foot the first push.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, it must not be, I will demand de Combat my self, I will Challenge him to morrow morning, I will bring you his heart for your Dinner, instead of de French Capon, and his guts shall serve instead of de Sawsage about it.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: That must be the French Admiral by his bragging, ugh; and the Rogue carries the Bastile about him; you take out my guts for Sawsages, Sirrah? Sirrah y'are the Son of a Whore, and I'll make a National Quarrel out.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Vell, Vell, I remember, Rascal, I remember.

div.stage: [O. Brag. Sings.] Remember ye Prigs what was formerly done.

sp.speaker: O. Brag.
sp.p: Where is this Rascal got now? I'll ferret him out of your holes i'faith, I'll find out your Ladyships ugh by places, I'll have him if he be above ground.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Go, Tear-shift after him, and let my Footmen use him at their discretion.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, here's the saddest-News you ever heard. Your Ladiships fine Daughter Ienny, and my ungracious Molly are both stole out to night from the Boarding-School, with Coopee and Semibrief.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Hah! what says the fellow?

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— dis is de Captain, de Blacksmith, and now turn'd Granadeer, begar.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Madam, I hope your Ladyship will excuse my disguise, but what Mr. Deputy says is very true, I dog'd ' emmy self, and have told him wherethey are.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: This ever comes of these plaguy Boarding-Schools, the Girls are always snap'd up by some Piping or Capring Fellow or other, if they are worth any thing— Come my Lady Stroddle, my Bowels yearn for the Jade, however I must go see whether she is undone or no.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Ah! dear Madam, what must I expect from your Ladyships favour—

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Who's there? bid some body give the Blacksmith here a Tester, and let him have my Custom for shooing my Coach-Horses— Come Monsieur, come let's go.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: And pray let us make haste Colonel, for you know the Rising is of greater concern to us than Children or Parents either.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Ah Morbleau, is it dere be de ver much difference?

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Give the Blacksmith a Tester, 'tis so, she's in the right, faith, for I have work'd at the Forge many a time, 'till I have earn'd it very dearly.
Ah dear Mrs. Tearshift I'm undone, my Lady has quite thrown me off, this old Scoundrel Father of mine has utterly ruin'd me.

sp.speaker: Tearsh.
sp.p: Why then ye have the means now to be reveng'd on him, for yonder he lies Drunk, and a sleep upon the Cellar stairs, and my Ladies Footmen are going to dress him up like a Dominican Friar, and as soon as he wakes intend to expose him to the Mob, I'm sorry I can't stay to see the sport— for I must after my Lady.

sp.speaker: Y. Brag.
sp.p: Gad. I'm glad of this however, for now will I be reveng'd of the Old Dogbolt— I'le go and enter my self amongst the Mob immediately, I'le be the Foreman of his Jury 'faith—

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter O. Merriton, Y. Merriton, Mirtilla, Coopee, Semibreif, Molly, Jenny, and Parson.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: NOw, Madam, I hope you are satisfied, I'll therefore leave ye in Possession, and go and get a Guard for our further Assistance. Gentlemen stand to your Post, you know your own Ladies are at stake.

sp.speaker: Coop.
sp.p: Doubt not, Sir, we are very happy to meet you, to give us this Protection.

sp.speaker: Semi.
sp.p: We'll defend our Fortunes now we have got 'em, I'll, warrant ye Sir— Come Domine, you are one of our Party.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis well, and I'll be with ye presently.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you'l defend your Fortune too?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: My Fortune is not worth defending, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: How, Sir, not worth defending— is my price fallen then?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Your price, ah no, I spoke of my own Fortune; your value, Madam, is inestimable, young, fair, and witty, Fifty Thousand Pounds too, and much good may it d'ye, I am not envious.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: All which I freely give to your dispose, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: By no means, Madam, I am no Usurer; your wisdom will do better to signify this to your Goldsmith, he'll mannage your full Baggs to an advantage, for my own part I deal in Hearts, not Money.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: My heart, Sir is yours, for now I can give it nobly, I've wealth enough.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: But I, alas, have not enough for you: I think 'twas once your saying.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: And do you then refuse me for a Saying?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: The Rich require no love, they expect reverence, and you see I keep my distance: When we were equal, then I lov'd ye dearly, I durst be bold then, now you are above me.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: I am not proud, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Not to your own thinking, a Woman's pride is just like one that squints, she seldom thinks she has the imperfection, because she never sees it.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Are not you proud now, to refuse a Blessing so strangely thrown upon ye? pray consider, Sir, are you not damnably proud?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: I have a noble fullenness of Soul, not proud, I never was a Slave to the Bawd Fortune, noy am I to be pufft up with her Benefits.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Must then your bravery of mind be shown to all the World but me, ah! where is now the Love you once protested?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Here in my breast, my heart is full of it; but, Madam, you would never entertain it, you set my heart still on the score of Fortune, 'twas not to be oblig'd to you but her; 'tis true, you argued prettily upon it, but too wise reasoning, shews too little Love.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: All Love without is madness.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Rapture you mean, and in that Rapture, Heaven, 'tis the Soul's general good enjoy'd in common, as well by the naked Beggar, as the Monarch; Fortune's a gift particular to Fools, to make amends for the Soul's gross defects, the blind work of Predestination, what must be, must be.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: I never yet did wish the Gifts of Fortune only to give 'em you.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: You should have given your self, in you was fortune, each precious minute you deferr'd my happiness, was greater loss than Fortune could repay me, now 'tis your Charity— I take it basely, 'tis Fifty Thousand Pounds given as an Alms.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: You are shrewdly hurt, to take the Alms of Love thus warmly heap'd in Gold— Come, come, you jest with me, you cannot leave me so.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Not so, I've yet some generous services to pay ye, when you are settled, then I'll tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: And more I hope to th' purpose.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: It may be so, mean time please to retire, here's Company coming. I should be a fool indeed, if I should lose thee for all my seeming [Exit Mirtil. fullenness, I know she's fast, therefore play this game, that hereafter she mayn't twit me with her benefits, Riches corrupt the Mind, some Women must be serv'd so.
sp.stage: Enter Amorous laughing, with a Scrivener.
sp.p: Here comes Amorous, whose merry tone will be turn'd too very suddenly.
Ha! Iack, well met; thour't very merry, I see, by which I guess the World goes well— hah—

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Beyond my expectation, faith. Dear Rogue, I have stript Iiltall, taken
away her Settlemement, and torn it; and have now brought this honest Fellow with Deeds here that give me a thousand a year, which my Uncle has this night promis'd to Seal. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: So; why, thou wett wrapt in thy Mother's Smock, sure, for thy luck: But prithee what is become of the Jilt now!

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt find her selling of Walnuts by the Fleet Ditch within these two days; footing of Stockings is above her level; she has not left a Nine-pence to buy Materials.

div.stage: Enter Jiltall richly dress'd, with Oyley, and three Footmen with Lights.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: 'Dslife, prithee look, is not that she yonder?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: No, that must be the Devil who has taken her likeness, and comes I believe with a design upon my Person.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Methinks Oyley, the Coach is not easie enough, I'll have the Cushions alter'd, and the Velvet finer; I'll have Six Horses too, I find every tawdry Gentlewoman has a couple.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Madam; and methinks your Ladyships Liveries are not fine enough neither.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: No, they have too much of the dull City Air; I'll make Sir Rowland change 'em. I'll have my Pages Coat cover'd with Gold Lace, and lin'd with Tissue.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Is this she that was selling Walnuts by the Fleet Ditch?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Damn her, this can be nothing but bouncing; you shall see me go and teize her about the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: What makes Sir Rowland stay so long, Oyley?

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: He's only talking with Mr. Dogsears the Parson a little, Madam, he'll be with ye presently.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Hoh, old Acquaintance; what, I see thou keep'st up still, I see thou wilt not want Rigging whilst there's a Cully in the Town.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: What means the Fellow? Who is this Rascal, Oyley?

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Some pitiful Shaggrag or other, Madam, of Aisatia, that wants to be kick'd by your Ladyships Footmen.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Do I so, eternal Common-shoar? No, they'll better serve for your Bitchships Recreation in the Larder at night. But, Betty, prithee why so resty? Lord, you Whores with Settlements are so Proud, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: If I did know thee to be a Fool, and not worth a Groat, I would ruine thee for that word. Hark ye, do you pretend to know me, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Cry ye Mercy, faith, may be I am bewitched and mistaken: but the Devil take me, if you do not look as like to a confounded Jilt of my acquaintance as one Thumb looks like another. Do'st hear, prithee, honest Fellow, who is that Lady? ha!

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Who is it? why, 'tis my Lady Rakehell: Sir Rowland will fleece your Coat, I can tell ye that, if he comes and sees ye sawcy with her.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Lady Rakehell, and Sir Rowland, what a Devil does this mean!

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: This cunning Jilt has counterplotted him, by Heaven; I find it.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why, heark ye, Fubbs, prithee how came thy Name to be alter'd? ha.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: 'Tis a disgrace to me to tell thee; but since 'tis the only honour I ever intend to do thee, know, Sirrah, I'm your Aunt, I am married to your Uncle, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: ‛ Oons, married to my Uncle!

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Ay, ay, married to your Uncle, Sirrah; what a Pox, won't the Fellow be answered?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, ye Jade, deny it again, and quickly, or I will have no more mercy on thee than—

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Help, help, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: What's this I see, my Rascally Nephew abusing Mistress Oyley? Sirrah, hands off, or I'le run my Sword in your Guts. What is your meaning for this Rogue? ha!

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Meaning, why, Sir, the impudent Quean would face me down that you were married to Iiltall my quondam Whore there.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: How, Sirrah, your Whore? Stand off, let me come to him, he shall never speak again, by this Blade.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Now for my last Game cunningly.

No, dear Sir Rowland, for my sake spare him now, because 'tis our Wedding day; 'tis true, he has been sawcy, and wicked, ungracious, and impudent, but let him scape for once, do dear, sweet, hony Sir Rowland, Alas! you know the poor Fellow is crack-brain'd.

div.stage: [She strokes and fawns on Sir Rowland.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Or shall be presently, 'faith, if this hold.
Well, Sir, to the discovery of that another time: Here the Scrivener has brought the Deed you order'd; will you please to go in and Seal?

div.stage: [Shews the Deed, and Rakehell strikes it out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Seal, 'oons ye Blockhead, I've married
The Heiress, what a Devil should I Seal?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why to the Thousand Pounds a Year you promis'd me, what a plague have ye forgot?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: I'll not give thee a Groat, get the Pox, take the Highway, Rob, come to the Gallows, and be damn'd, a fair riddance—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Alas, if my dear-Husband here should Seal to the Settlement, in one of your mad fits, Cousin, you'd tear it some time or other.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: A Pox Cousin ye,— I'm resolv'd this Devil shall never carry it off so, however; why then, Sir, I must tell ye, that you are cheated too, for she's no more the right Heiress than I am, but, as I told ye before, my Cast off Wench, and her Name is Iiltall—

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Ay, make him believe that if thou canst, Fool [Aside to Amorous. Ha, ha, ha, d'ye hear him, Sir, d'ye hear him;

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Ay, ay— A Pox on him, but I'll not endure this; I'll send the Dog to Bedlam to morrow— but come, my Dear— Supper stays for us— thou 'rt welcome now to thine own House— Sirrah, go and get open the door.

div.stage: [Footman goes to the Door, and young Merriton interposes.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Who would you speak with, Friend?
Have you any business here—

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Business here, Sir, yes that I have.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: To me then.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: To you! I've nothing to say to you, my Business is with the Porter.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: I am the Porter.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: How, now, Sir, you the Porter, pray since when, I never entertain'd ye that I remember?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: The Lady of the House has, that's enough, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Who, I? what does he mean, I never entertain'd him, not I.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: You never did, indeed; alas, how should ye? you are not the Lady of the House—

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: No, Sir, then I hope you'l give me leave to be Lord on't, I hope I may come in?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Not a Foot further, Sir, my Lady has given orders to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: A pox on your Lady, what have I to do with her; 'oons must not I bring my Wife into my own House for her?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: You may if you please, Sir, but this is none of it, this my Ladies House.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: I believe Merriton has contriv'd this trick for my sake; come dear Will, shall I come in then, dear Rogue?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Nor you neither, Sir, I must beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Pardon, prithee what dost thou mean, is the Devil in thee?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Hey day! here's another madd Puppy— the Town swarms with 'em now as thick as Wasps in Summer; what hoa— whos's within there, Old Merriton— Orthodox, Pew-pimp, where are ye in the Devil's Name?

div.stage: Enter Old Merriton with Guard at distance.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: To one of my Names I answer, what's your pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: ‛ Oons, to go in, Sir— and to carry in this sweet Lady, Sir, quick, quick, ye old Homily, I've wonders to tell thee, Rogue.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: I have wonders to tell you, Sir Rowland.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: A pox o' thy wonders, thou hast 'em all out of the Apocrypha, I'll not hear one of 'em before Supper; 'sbud, open the Door there.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: You will not force, Sir, into a Ladies House without her leave?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: A Ladies House— ha, ha, ha, old Deutrinomy's mad too, or has the old Hipocrite got a Whore into my House, and lovingly given her the Possession?

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: No, Sir, the Lady within is the right Owner of the House, Sir William Wealthy's Daughter; she, you and I kidnab'd to the Indies, Sir, who has, to tell you the truth, with my Assistance, now made hard shift to get back to seize her own.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— 'tis so, he's Craz'd, poor Religion is stark mad by this light, the Owner within, ye lie, here she stands; speak, my Dear, art not thou the true Heiress— hah, prithee speak and confound the silly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Why then, if I must speak, not I, Faith, Sir, therefore look to your self.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Not the Heiress, 'oons, what a Devil art thou then?

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: A very good Gentlewoman, I assure ye, Sir Rowland—

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: I told ye once before, she's an old Acquaintance of mine, an admirable Backsword-player; 'tis true, she's not worth a Groat, but she can knit well, or make Buttons: will you Seal yet, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Oh the Devil, I am chous'd, abus'd, undone!

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: A mistake only in the Woman, Sir, here comes a Lady will clear all.
Your Guardian, Madam— but perhaps you have forgot him.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I have, but not his Vices, which I'll not reprove, because I'le leave the Law to do it for me; in the mean time 'tis satisfaction for me that I dare seize my own.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: My little pretty Tit of the Boarding-School, by all that's good, this subtle old Fellow, I find, has fool'd me damnably.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: Her own Furies and Hell, am I then gull'd at last?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: 'Sbud draw, I'le make a forcible entry; I'le not be fool'd thus: Draw, Nephew, and I will Seal.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Not I; draw to Newgate, to Tyburn, be Condemned, Carted, Halter'd, Hoisted and Hang'd, if you please, I'le not draw an inch, not I.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, we are ready for ye, Sir; seise on him there, and secure him till the Law determine further.

And now y'are hamper'd, Sir, know that our former Agreement of Spiritting away to th' Indies this young Lady, the right Heiress to Sir William Wealthy, was always odious to me, which I had then discover'd and secur'd her, had I not known your Crowded Coffers would have out-talk'd my honesty, I therefore took this way, and seeming readily to pack her off, convey'd her privately to a Boarding-School, where the two hundred pounds a Year allow'd me for that honourable Action, I have faithfully laid out on her in Breeding, thus sav'd her from your mischievous Intentions, and well rewarded in the grateful Action.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: I have made a fine days work of this! not so much for losing three thousand a year, as for marrying a three pil'd Whore, for an Heiress— but there's one comfort still, she is not like to get a Groat by me.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: If I had known that, I'de as soon have married the Hangman.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: What does your Ladyship think of a Page now, cover'd with Gold-Lace, and lin'd with Tissue.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I'de poison him, as I would thee, and all the World.

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: If I did not dream of Woollen Stockens last night, I'me no Christian.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: The House I stand possest of, and the Writings, which give me Title as my Father's Heir, all which, Sir, * * To old Mer. being about to choose me a new Guardian, I have offered, nay, with my self, to an ungrateful Man that has refus'd me.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: And has he his Wits left?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Whoever, Madam, that stupid Creature is, you shall find me more tractable, and if you please, you may remember, Madam—

div.stage: [Brisking up to her, Y. Mer. interposes.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! this is a Jem too Rich to lose; and, as you say, he must be very stupid, that, kindly proffer'd can deny to wear it— I hope, I may succeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mirt.
sp.p: I need not speak, my heart too much pleads for ye.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Pox, fopp'd again, the Devil's in my Fortune, hark'e, Sir, you have chous'd me finely here,

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: Only Wit outwitted, Iack, no chouce, I onely diverted thee a little, for my Son's sake; thou know'st Natural affection is unblameable.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Diverted me! a pretty Epithete, he has diverted me from fifty thousand
pounds, with a Pox to him; a fine diversion indeed— A plague of my shallow Pate.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: Mr. Constable, there's your Warrant, go and secure Sir Rowland till further order; Crimes of this Nature must not be wink'd at, nor can I refuse my Evidence, and be honest.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: Honest! a Fellow with a Face of thy Levitical Cut, honest! and a Rogue that knows too, there's no such thing in Nature.

sp.speaker: O. Mer.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.p: No! does not the Forreigner cheat the Country, the Country cheat the City, the City cheat the Courtier, the Courtier cheat the King, the Robber cheat the Fur-Coat, the Fur-Coat cheat the Red-Coat, the Red-Coat cheat the Petty-Coat, the Petty-Coat cheat the Black-Coat, and the Black-Coat cheat us all! and yet thou pratest of Honesty, Honesty; prithee Cant, pray on, and be damn'd, for that thou wilt come too for all thy Honesty; and so farewel.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Godbuye, Uncle, here's my Settlement in a fine Condition.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Well Iack, thou shalt be no loser by my Fortune, I know thy Ravenous Uncle has suck'd up a great part of thy Estate by means unjust, which we'll return, and set thee up anew; see, Betty smiles at that.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: And shall we sawn, and stroke, and kiss, and spett at one another again? Hah, my dear, dear, damn'd Crockadile, hah!

sp.speaker: Oyley.
sp.p: Plague on 'em, they laugh at us; come away, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iilt.
sp.p: I come; but I'm resolv'd I'le leave one swinging Curse behind me first.
sp.l: May Whores lose, thee, and all thy Race, Salvation;
Breed want, the Pox, Murder, and Desolation;
And damn ye to the twentieth Generation.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Hah, hah, ha; Adieu Buttock; and Gad little did I think that ever I should have had the Heart to have said so; but come, there's an end on't. How now, who have we here, more House-warmers?

div.stage: Enter L. Addleplott, L. Stroddle, Nicompoop, Le Prat, and Tearshift.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Where is this Wretch, this degenerate Creature, that is so eager for Man before she is capable, this Cub of thirteen, with the Devil in her already? Where must I find her? hah!

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: This is the House, an't please your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: L. Prat.
sp.p: Dis is de House begar of Sir Rowland Rakehell

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Begar you lie; and therefore stand further off: Hey, what a Plague, d'ye come to besiege my House?

sp.speaker: L. Prat.
sp.p: Your House, Morbleau? but dat is ver strange.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, strange and true! Therefore dance your distance.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: I hope your are not accessary to the Childrens Rape, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Not I, Faith; all your Ladiships Children have a better faculty themselves than to want Accessaries.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Very well, Sir; you may chance to swing for this; for my Daughter is an Heiress.

sp.speaker: Y. Mer.
sp.p: Oh, I'll venture that; they are within there with two honest ingenious young Fellows, who I think are Married to 'em; and for my part I could not civilly deny 'em the protection of my House. See, I suppose they have heard your voice, and are come of their own accord.

div.stage: Enter Jenny, Molly, Coopee, Semibrief, and Parson.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Ay, ay, there has been some mischief done, I'm sure, for yonder's a Parson with 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: D'ye know your Mother, Hussie? Come hither.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: Oh, but I won't tho, you'll whip me.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: And hast thou ungraciously taken Man without my leave, Molly?

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Yes indeed have I, therefore hold your self contented.

sp.speaker: Semibr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, well said, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Ienny.
sp.p: However, whereof I am married, pray, the Man asked Mr. Coopee a Question, and he said ay; and then he ask'd me a Question, and I said ay; and then we both joyned hands together, and so we were married as fast as any thing.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: You have not consummated the Jade, and therefore I'll unmarry you again.

sp.speaker: Parson.
sp.p: Verily they have done as became them Both, I was an eye witness.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: An eye witness! there's a pimping fanatical Rogue for you now.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Ivads I like it very well, I wish I had been married sooner for my part, for I begin to love Mr. Semibrief since we bedded, better than my bread and butter by half.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: This comes of putting Girls to a Boarding-School.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Ay, they hop, and dance till they set their blood on fire, and then they quench it with the next puddle they come at seriously.
A Rogue, a Fryer, down with him, down with him.

div.stage: Enter Old Bragg in a Fryers habit, the Mobb after him, and Young Bragg as their Captain.

sp.speaker: Old Bragg.
sp.p: Help, help, Murder, Murder, I'm pursued, I'm taken, I'm kill'd, help, help.

sp.speaker: Y. Bragg.
sp.p: Oh we'll bring you to life again presently, you old Scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: There's Money for ye, I'll purchase his Liberty for once; and d'ye hear, yonder's a better subject for you by half, my Lady there; now you have a rare time to revenge your self, and seize on her and her Party; I know they'r hatching something against the Government.

sp.speaker: Young Bragg.
sp.p: I'll do't, fall on friends— By your leave, Madam, I must secure you, you have done as much for me you know many a time: 'tis true, yours was a fairer way, but we Politicians must not value Niceties of honour, we have an Advantage, therefore I, the Blacksmith and Captain confine you Prisoner to the State.

sp.speaker: Mobb.
sp.p: And I the Chimney-sweeper a Lieutenant, justifie him in't.

sp.speaker: L. Addle.
sp.p: Nay I know the Government's afraid of me, I have been told as much; but for thy own part, look to't that I don't meet thee hereafter, for if I do, if there be a Capon in Christendom I'll make thee one; I'll teach you to disarm the Colonel of the Ladies, you Limberham's Rascal you.

sp.speaker: L. Strod.
sp.p: If ever we live to see good days again, look to your selves, Rebels.

sp.speaker: Le Prat.
sp.p: Or twenty towsand French upon London-Bridge, as Notredame assure us— den you shall see vat de French can do; den Mortbleau you shall se de great Monarch—

sp.speaker: Young Bragg.
sp.p: Ah, stop his mouth there, down with him, a French Rascal.

sp.speaker: Nicom.
sp.p: Well, I hope we shall have peace for all this, for I am weary of my Buff, seriously.

sp.speaker: Old Bragg.
sp.p: And so am I of my Sables, here I'm sure 'dsdeath could they find no other way to disgrace me, but to stink me with an old Fox Hide, and choak me up in the fur of a Fryer, now shall I stink of Popery for this Month at least, which is a worse smell to me, then an Old Jew that is telling a Story, and has just rellish'd his Mouth with a Clove of Garlick.

sp.speaker: Old Merr.
sp.p: Come, Madam, your Supper is ready within, where you shall give me leave to drink Prosperity to the King and Government, not forgetting some new Consummations.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: And if I do haphen to be drunk with toping thine and thy blessings Health, there thou'lt be so kind, Friend, as to remember the mortgage in the morning, hah—

sp.speaker: Young Mer.
sp.p: Oh never doubt me, I'll not break my Word— and now sweet Angel, my Joys crowd thick about my heart, and long for vent, the approaching happiness looks so like Heaven, that I methinks am extasied already.

sp.speaker: Mirtil.
sp.p: Nor is my share of vast Content less Charming.
sp.l: In Fortune's brightest Sphere of Bliss I move,
Enjoying Wealth enough, and him I Love.
